questions.question: What did Loftus and Palmer (1974) find regarding the impact of leading questions on eyewitness testimony?
options: Participants estimated higher speeds with the word 'smashed'
Participants recalled more details with the word 'hit'
Participants were less confident with leading questions
Participants showed no difference in speed estimates
questions.explanation: The study showed that the wording of questions significantly influenced speed estimates, with 'smashed' leading to higher estimates. This corresponds to: Participants estimated higher speeds with the word 'smashed'.

questions.question: In the context of eyewitness testimony, what is meant by 'post-event discussion'?
options: A conversation that occurs before the event
An interview conducted by police
A conversation between witnesses after the event
A method to enhance memory recall
questions.explanation: Post-event discussion refers to conversations between co-witnesses or interviewers that can alter a witness's memory. This corresponds to: A conversation between witnesses after the event.

questions.question: How does anxiety affect eyewitness testimony according to research?
options: It always improves recall accuracy
It has no effect on memory
It can lead to physiological arousal that may impair memory
It only affects children
questions.explanation: Research indicates that anxiety can lead to physiological arousal, which may impair the accuracy of eyewitness memory. This corresponds to: It can lead to physiological arousal that may impair memory.

questions.question: In a scenario where a witness is asked leading questions, what is a potential outcome?
options: The witness will always remember correctly
The witness's memory may be altered
The witness will provide more details
The witness will forget the event entirely
questions.explanation: Leading questions can introduce misleading information that alters the witness's memory of the event. This corresponds to: The witness's memory may be altered.

questions.question: What is one criticism of Loftus and Palmer's (1974) study regarding ecological validity?
options: The study used real-life witnesses
The video of a car crash may not evoke real emotional responses
Participants were not aware of the study's aims
The sample size was too large
questions.explanation: The use of a video may lack the emotional intensity of a real car crash, affecting the generalizability of the findings. This corresponds to: The video of a car crash may not evoke real emotional responses.

questions.question: Which technique is NOT part of the cognitive interview?
options: Changing perspective
Report everything
Leading questions
Context reinstatement
questions.explanation: Leading questions are not part of the cognitive interview; instead, techniques aim to enhance memory recall

questions.question: What effect can misleading information have on eyewitness testimony?
options: It can enhance memory recall
It can lead to memory contamination
It has no effect on memory
It only affects children
questions.explanation: Misleading information can contaminate a witness's memory, leading to inaccuracies in their testimony. This corresponds to: It can lead to memory contamination.

questions.question: What is a potential methodological issue with studies on eyewitness testimony?
options: They often use real-life scenarios
They may involve demand characteristics
They always have a large sample size
They do not use leading questions
questions.explanation: Participants may guess the aims of the study, leading to demand characteristics that can skew results. This corresponds to: They may involve demand characteristics.

questions.question: How does the cognitive interview aim to improve eyewitness testimony?
options: By using leading questions
By encouraging witnesses to recall everything
By limiting the amount of information shared
By avoiding any discussion with witnesses
questions.explanation: The cognitive interview encourages witnesses to report everything they remember, which can improve the accuracy of their testimony. This corresponds to: By encouraging witnesses to recall everything.

questions.question: What is one way that anxiety can impact eyewitness memory according to research?
options: It always enhances memory recall
It can lead to physiological arousal that may impair memory
It has no measurable effects
It only affects adults
questions.explanation: Anxiety can cause physiological arousal, which may negatively impact the accuracy of eyewitness memory. This corresponds to: It can lead to physiological arousal that may impair memory.
